neighbors.name: Legg George W III & Daphne V
neighbors.claims: George W. Legg III sued Dorchester County in 2002, claiming that seepage from the county’s closed landfill polluted his family’s adjacent farm near Secretary, MD ([thedailyrecord.com](https://thedailyrecord.com/2002/05/20/no-taking-but-maybe-a-nuisance-29885/#:~:text=In%201974%2C%20Legg%E2%80%99s%20grandmother%20leased,wanted%20to%20sell%20for%20development)) ([thedailyrecord.com](https://thedailyrecord.com/2002/05/20/no-taking-but-maybe-a-nuisance-29885/#:~:text=In%20February%201998%2C%20Legg%E2%80%99s%20attorney,a%20potential%20buyer%20in%201996)). He had intended to subdivide and sell roughly 16.5 acres of that farm for residential development, but a 1996 Maryland environmental report warned that landfill contaminants could taint any new wells on his property, scuttling a planned sale ([thedailyrecord.com](https://thedailyrecord.com/2002/05/20/no-taking-but-maybe-a-nuisance-29885/#:~:text=Motz%20found%20that%20Legg%20was,Also%2C%20methane%20gas%20from%20the)) ([thedailyrecord.com](https://thedailyrecord.com/2002/05/20/no-taking-but-maybe-a-nuisance-29885/#:~:text=The%20county%20rejected%20Legg%E2%80%99s%20offer,filed%20suit%20in%20January%202002)). Legg even offered to sell the affected land to the County in 1998 – blaming the landfill for his failed 1996 deal – but County officials rejected his offer ([thedailyrecord.com](https://thedailyrecord.com/2002/05/20/no-taking-but-maybe-a-nuisance-29885/#:~:text=In%20February%201998%2C%20Legg%E2%80%99s%20attorney,a%20potential%20buyer%20in%201996)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have an environmental specialist meet with Legg to acknowledge his past landfill issues and emphasize strong protections for groundwater and property value in the new project.

neighbors.name: Windsor John R & Marion H
neighbors.claims: John R. Windsor is a second-generation Dorchester County farmer who lives with his wife Marion in East New Market, MD ([www.newcombcollins.com](https://www.newcombcollins.com/obituaries/Frederick-Windsor#:~:text=Windsor%20Yale%20of%20Potomac%2C%20MD%2C,DC%2C%20John%20Robert%20Windsor%20Jr)). He comes from a prominent local farm family – his late father, Frederick “Freddie” Windsor, was a lifelong Dorchester farmer who served as president of the Linkwood-Salem Volunteer Fire Company and was active in the county Farm Bureau ([www.newcombcollins.com](https://www.newcombcollins.com/obituaries/Frederick-Windsor#:~:text=place%20trophies)). John and his siblings grew up working on the family farm; as adults, he and his brother each established their own farming operations in the county ([www.newcombcollins.com](https://www.newcombcollins.com/obituaries/Frederick-Windsor#:~:text=Cambridge%20and%20moved%20to%20the,at%20the%20age%20of%2080)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage through a respected agriculture community liaison. Emphasize respect for farming heritage and explain how the project will safeguard farmland and local traditions.

neighbors.name: Hurley Wilbur F Jr
neighbors.claims: Wilbur F. Hurley Jr. is listed as an owner of property near Linkwood WMA but has no public presence in local government or media ([dcgm.tripod.com](https://dcgm.tripod.com/dcgmefindex.html#:~:text=HURLEY%2C%20Jason%20d%20Mar%201866,Obit)) ([dcgm.tripod.com](https://dcgm.tripod.com/dcgmefindex.html#:~:text=HURLEY%2C%20Ware%20W.%20,N%201%20Dec%201883)). His family name is common in Dorchester County, yet no recent news, civic records, or leadership roles were found associated with him, indicating he maintains a very low public profile ([dcgm.tripod.com](https://dcgm.tripod.com/dcgmefindex.html#:~:text=HURLEY%2C%20Jason%20d%20Mar%201866,Obit)) ([dcgm.tripod.com](https://dcgm.tripod.com/dcgmefindex.html#:~:text=HURLEY%2C%20Ware%20W.%20,N%201%20Dec%201883)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach via a personal, low-key visit by a community member. Emphasize minimal disruption to his daily life and the quiet rural character of the area.

neighbors.name: Secrist Kevin Baker And [co-owner]
neighbors.claims: Kevin B. Secrist is identified as a parcel owner, but he does not appear in any Dorchester County civic records, news archives, or community organizations ([www.locatefamily.com](https://www.locatefamily.com/S/SEC/SECRIST-37.html#:~:text=Worldwide%20www,call%20Jake%20Secrist%20by%20telephone)). No biographical details or local involvement for Secrist could be verified in public sources, suggesting he is not an active figure in the community’s public affairs ([www.locatefamily.com](https://www.locatefamily.com/S/SEC/SECRIST-37.html#:~:text=Worldwide%20www,call%20Jake%20Secrist%20by%20telephone)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Provide clear, straightforward information via mail or phone. Since Secrist isn’t locally engaged, focus on factual benefits (e.g. property protections, minimal disturbances) to address any concerns he may have.

neighbors.name: Travers Brett W
neighbors.claims: Brett W. Travers shares a surname with one of Dorchester County’s historically influential families – 19th-century records refer to the Travers family as a distinguished lineage of large landowners in the county ([msa.maryland.gov](https://msa.maryland.gov/megafile/msa/speccol/sc5400/sc5496/051300/051327/html/51327bio.html#:~:text=Levi%20D,1%2C%202)). While the Travers name is represented in current local leadership (for example, County Councilman Ricky Travers) ([abcdocz.com](https://abcdocz.com/doc/1119203/to-view-the-april-7--2015-regular-session-meeting-minutes#:~:text=the%20following%20members%20present%3A%20Ricky,Also%20present%20were)), Brett himself has not been mentioned in local news or public meetings, indicating he has stayed out of the spotlight and any development debates so far.

approach_recommendations.engage: Meet through a mutual local contact (such as a community or family connection) to respect hometown dynamics. Discuss how the project will be guided by local input and bring economic benefits to Dorchester County.

neighbors.name: James W. Phillips Jr. et al.
neighbors.claims: James W. Phillips Jr. has served as Dorchester County Sheriff since 2002 ([msa.maryland.gov](https://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdmanual/36loc/do/jud/sheriffs/html/msa14125.html#:~:text=Sheriff%2C%20Dorchester%20County%2C%20since%20December,former%20chief%20deputy)). He also chairs the county Recreation and Parks Board and sits on the Drug and Alcohol Abuse Council, reflecting a significant local leadership role ([msa.maryland.gov](https://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdmanual/36loc/do/jud/sheriffs/html/msa14125.html#:~:text=Member%2C%20Drug%20and%20Alcohol%20Abuse,Wic%20Community%20College)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage via formal briefing with county officials to ensure Sheriff Phillips is informed. Emphasize public safety measures and community benefits while addressing any law enforcement or traffic concerns.

neighbors.name: Justin T. Koshar
neighbors.claims: Justin T. Koshar is a local property owner with no public record of involvement in civic groups or local government ([mdfarmbureau.com](https://mdfarmbureau.com/dorchester-county-board-of-directors/#:~:text=BOARD%20MEMBERS)). His name does not appear in known community leadership lists, suggesting a low public profile ([mdfarmbureau.com](https://mdfarmbureau.com/dorchester-county-board-of-directors/#:~:text=BOARD%20MEMBERS)).

approach_recommendations.engage: A personal one-on-one outreach is recommended to hear any concerns he may have. Emphasize open communication and the steps being taken to minimize impacts on his property and lifestyle.

neighbors.name: Tyler Lee Mabry
neighbors.claims: Tyler Lee Mabry owns multiple parcels in the area (per county records) but holds no visible role in local organizations ([mdfarmbureau.com](https://mdfarmbureau.com/dorchester-county-board-of-directors/#:~:text=Dale%20Collins%20Barbara%20Edgar%20Trent,Mike%20Nicholas%20Max%20Schnoor%2C%20Jr)). His absence from community or agricultural leadership forums indicates a limited public presence ([mdfarmbureau.com](https://mdfarmbureau.com/dorchester-county-board-of-directors/#:~:text=Dale%20Collins%20Barbara%20Edgar%20Trent,Mike%20Nicholas%20Max%20Schnoor%2C%20Jr)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out with a neighborly approach to discuss the project’s plans. Highlight any measures protecting farmland and address practical issues like drainage or access to ensure his land interests are respected.

neighbors.name: Warwick Manor Behavioral Health
neighbors.claims: See ORG table.

approach_recommendations.engage: Handled in organization-level outreach.

neighbors.name: Charles Andrew Clow
neighbors.claims: Charles Andrew Clow has no noted involvement in public meetings or local committees ([mdfarmbureau.com](https://mdfarmbureau.com/dorchester-county-board-of-directors/#:~:text=BOARD%20MEMBERS)). Public records do not show him in any community leadership positions, implying a low-profile local presence ([mdfarmbureau.com](https://mdfarmbureau.com/dorchester-county-board-of-directors/#:~:text=BOARD%20MEMBERS)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Use a friendly, informal approach to introduce the project and listen to any concerns. Emphasize that the development will respect residential peace and not adversely affect surrounding properties.

neighbors.name: Arthur S. Clough
neighbors.claims: Arthur S. Clough is a private landowner in Dorchester County’s rural Linkwood area ([dnr.maryland.gov](https://dnr.maryland.gov/wildlife/pages/publiclands/eastern/linkwood.aspx#:~:text=Linkwood%20WMA)). No evidence was found of Clough holding any public office or speaking out on local development issues ([msa.maryland.gov](https://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdmanual/36loc/do/html/doe.html#:~:text=Maryland,mail%3A%20lpfeffer%40dorchestermd.gov%20web%3A%20www.dorchestermd.gov)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach one-on-one through a familiar local intermediary to build trust, as he has maintained a low profile and may respond best to personal, respectful outreach.

neighbors.name: Christopher Roop
neighbors.claims: Christopher Roop is listed as a landowner in the same Linkwood vicinity of Dorchester County ([dnr.maryland.gov](https://dnr.maryland.gov/wildlife/pages/publiclands/eastern/linkwood.aspx#:~:text=Linkwood%20WMA)). He has no known public profile in community affairs, and no records of him taking a stance on development have been found ([msa.maryland.gov](https://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdmanual/36loc/do/html/doe.html#:~:text=Maryland,mail%3A%20lpfeffer%40dorchestermd.gov%20web%3A%20www.dorchestermd.gov)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage him in a straightforward, informal conversation (possibly via a neighbor he knows) to understand his concerns, since he has stayed out of the public eye.

neighbors.name: Rachel Lewis
neighbors.claims: Rachel Lewis appears to be a local property owner with no accompanying public record of civic involvement ([msa.maryland.gov](https://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdmanual/36loc/do/html/doe.html#:~:text=Maryland,mail%3A%20lpfeffer%40dorchestermd.gov%20web%3A%20www.dorchestermd.gov)). There are no public statements or articles linking her to any position on development or land use debates in Dorchester County ([msa.maryland.gov](https://msa.maryland.gov/msa/mdmanual/36loc/do/html/doe.html#:~:text=Maryland,mail%3A%20lpfeffer%40dorchestermd.gov%20web%3A%20www.dorchestermd.gov)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Invite her to a community information meeting or a one-on-one visit to share project details and listen to any concerns, as she has not publicly voiced opinions.

neighbors.name: Hattie S. Thompson
neighbors.claims: Hattie S. Thompson was an 85-year-old lifelong Dorchester County resident who passed away in April 2007 ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/baytobaynews-md/name/hattie-thompson-obituary?id=50301300#:~:text=Hattie%20Thompson%20HURLOCK%20,God%20in%20East%20New%20Market)). She devoted herself to family and community church life and never held public office or led any civic campaigns ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/baytobaynews-md/name/hattie-thompson-obituary?id=50301300#:~:text=Mrs,God%20in%20East%20New%20Market)). There is no record of her having taken any public position regarding development projects ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/baytobaynews-md/name/hattie-thompson-obituary?id=50301300#:~:text=Mrs,God%20in%20East%20New%20Market)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Since she is deceased, outreach should be directed to her heirs or estate representatives (such as her surviving son) to understand their plans and address any inheritance-related concerns sensitively.

neighbors.name: Richard & Angela K. Norfolk
neighbors.claims: Richard H. Norfolk, Jr., 66, was a long-time Dorchester County resident (East New Market) who passed away in November 2024 ([www.thomasfuneralhomepa.com](https://www.thomasfuneralhomepa.com/obituaries/richard-h-norfolk-jr#:~:text=Richard%20H,Norfolk%2C%20Sr)). A retired UPS employee who enjoyed outdoor activities and family time, he was not involved in local politics or activism ([www.thomasfuneralhomepa.com](https://www.thomasfuneralhomepa.com/obituaries/richard-h-norfolk-jr#:~:text=Rick%20graduated%20from%20Glen%20Burnie,of%20AA%20for%2036%20years)). His wife, Angela K. Norfolk, survives him, and neither has been noted making any public comments for or against development initiatives ([www.thomasfuneralhomepa.com](https://www.thomasfuneralhomepa.com/obituaries/richard-h-norfolk-jr#:~:text=He%20is%20survived%20by%20his,grandchildren%2C%20and%20five%20great%20grandchildren)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Retired local; not a public figure

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Angela Norfolk with empathy and personal outreach, acknowledging the family’s long residence and assuring that any project plans will respect their privacy and the character of the community.

neighbors.name: Mendiola Meliton Alberto Garcia
neighbors.claims: Meliton Alberto Garcia is listed as an owner of a parcel on Linkwood Road near the Linkwood community in Dorchester County [Dorchester Chamber of Commerce](https://www.dorchesterchamber.org/news/details/public-notice-from-rwe-clean-energy). No evidence of Garcia’s involvement in local civic affairs or any public stance on development was found; the only references to his name were outside Maryland (e.g., a South Carolina report) [Patch (Summerville, SC)](https://patch.com/south-carolina/summerville/busted-arrest-reports-for-dec-23).

approach_recommendations.engage: As an absent or low-profile landowner, initial outreach via a polite formal letter or phone call—sharing project details and inviting questions—may help build trust and gauge his interest.

neighbors.name: Sean P. Reincke and Susan K. Reincke
neighbors.claims: Sean P. Reincke is a teacher at Cambridge-South Dorchester High School, indicating he is an active local community member [Cambridge-South Dorchester HS Staff Directory](https://www.dcps.k12.md.us/o/cambridgesouth/staff?page_no=4). Neither Sean nor Susan Reincke holds a public office or has been noted speaking on development issues in any local records or media [Maryland Manual – Dorchester County](https://2022mdmanual.msa.maryland.gov/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage the Reinckes through a friendly, personal approach (e.g., at a community event or via a neighborly visit) and emphasize transparency and facts; as an educator, Sean may appreciate open dialogue about the project.

neighbors.name: Doretha O. Abraham
neighbors.claims: Doretha O. Abraham is a long-time local landowner; property records also list her as Doretha Dockins Abraham, reflecting a family name with deep roots in Dorchester County [Free Dorchester Obituary Index](http://dcgm.tripod.com/dcgmcdindex.html#99). She has no recorded participation in public meetings or committees and has not taken any documented stance on development or energy projects [Maryland Manual – Dorchester County](https://2022mdmanual.msa.maryland.gov/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach Mrs. Abraham with respect for her long family tenure in the area. A personal visit by a community liaison emphasizing the project’s respect for local land and heritage may address any legacy or land-preservation concerns she could have.

neighbors.name: Mary Elizabeth Scott et al
neighbors.claims: Mary Elizabeth Scott (with “et al” indicating other family co-owners) holds an ownership stake in land in the Linkwood vicinity of Dorchester County [Dorchester Chamber of Commerce](https://www.dorchesterchamber.org/news/details/public-notice-from-rwe-clean-energy). She does not serve in any public leadership capacity, and there are no public statements from her regarding local development in available records [Maryland Manual – Dorchester County](https://2022mdmanual.msa.maryland.gov/).

approach_recommendations.engage: Use a neighborly, informal approach—perhaps through an introduction by a mutual acquaintance or local community meeting—to share information about the project. Emphasize community benefits and listen to any family concerns to build goodwill.

neighbors.name: Adedapo Olutoyin Amos
neighbors.claims: Adedapo O. Amos owns property in the vicinity of the Linkwood Wildlife Management Area in Dorchester County and has no documented involvement in local development issues ([visitdorchester.org](https://visitdorchester.org/listing/linkwood-wildlife-management-area#:~:text=A%20remnant%20of%20a%20larger,wide%20range%20of%20forest%20animals)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Use personal, one-on-one outreach to introduce the project and listen to any concerns, given his lack of a public stance.

neighbors.name: Donald L. Cheesman Sr.
neighbors.claims: Donald L. Cheesman Sr. comes from a multi-generational Dorchester farming family – his late father, Thomas E. Cheesman Sr., was a lifelong farmer and Farm Bureau member ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/newszapmd/name/thomas-cheesman-obituary?id=24602226#:~:text=Thomas%20Edward%20Cheesman%20Sr,14%2C%202008%2C%20in)). The Cheesman family remains active in local agriculture, as Donald L. Cheesman Jr. of East New Market received about $1,627 in recent farm support payments ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=24019&page=8&progcode=tot_cfap2#:~:text=171%20%20,%241%2C540)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected local farmer or agricultural leader reach out, emphasizing that the project will protect farmland use and respect the family’s farming legacy.

neighbors.name: Benjamin Connor Doyle
neighbors.claims: Benjamin C. Doyle owns land near the Linkwood WMA in Dorchester County and has not taken any public role or position in local development issues ([visitdorchester.org](https://visitdorchester.org/listing/linkwood-wildlife-management-area#:~:text=A%20remnant%20of%20a%20larger,wide%20range%20of%20forest%20animals)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage him directly with an introductory conversation, focusing on understanding any personal concerns since he has not voiced opinions publicly.

neighbors.name: Kevin C. Parker Sr. et al.
neighbors.claims: Kevin C. Parker Sr. (and co-owners) hold property around the Linkwood Wildlife Management Area, but he has not been prominently involved in community or development discussions ([visitdorchester.org](https://visitdorchester.org/listing/linkwood-wildlife-management-area#:~:text=A%20remnant%20of%20a%20larger,wide%20range%20of%20forest%20animals)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Family landowner; not in public spotlight

approach_recommendations.engage: Include his family in outreach and emphasize local control – reassure them the project will not undermine their land’s long-term value or heritage.

neighbors.name: Jeffrey S. Graybill
neighbors.claims: Jeffrey S. Graybill is a landowner near the Linkwood WMA in Dorchester County and has no recorded public stance or civic engagement regarding development proposals ([visitdorchester.org](https://visitdorchester.org/listing/linkwood-wildlife-management-area#:~:text=A%20remnant%20of%20a%20larger,wide%20range%20of%20forest%20animals)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Reach out with a neighborly approach and provide information calmly, addressing any questions to build trust, as he has not been active publicly on these issues.

neighbors.name: Anna Mae Dockins
neighbors.claims: Anna Mae Dockins holds a life estate interest in a rural parcel in Dorchester County, Maryland ([www.wboc.com](https://www.wboc.com/archive/east-new-market-citizens-concerned-about-solar-farm-project/article_23b7861f-6bd3-5c6f-8422-e5a52ced3933.html#:~:text=The%20fields%20around%20East%20New,about%20the%20prospect%20of%20solar)). Her family name is associated with a longtime service station in the East New Market area of the county ([www.mapquest.com](https://www.mapquest.com/us/maryland/dockins-service-station-2704587#:~:text=Dockins%20Service%20Station%2C%204102%20E,4113%20http%3A%2F%2Fshell.com%20Dockins%20Service%20Station)). No record of her speaking at public meetings or holding civic positions was found ([www.wboc.com](https://www.wboc.com/archive/east-new-market-citizens-concerned-about-solar-farm-project/article_23b7861f-6bd3-5c6f-8422-e5a52ced3933.html#:~:text=WBOC%20spoke%20with%20neighbors%20at,are%20concerned%20about%20this%20project)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Have a respected local neighbor or agricultural extension agent reach out to discuss how the project will protect farmland character and minimize visual impact on her property.

neighbors.name: Brenda Faye Era
neighbors.claims: Brenda Faye Era is part of a locally rooted family; she is the wife of the late Joseph G. Era III of Cambridge, who was active as a church trustee, American Legion member, and Ruritan Club president ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/baytobaynews-md/name/joseph-era-obituary?id=20351615#:~:text=dog%2C%20Pancho,Deborah)). The Era family maintains deep ties in Dorchester County, with relatives in nearby communities like Secretary and Hurlock ([www.legacy.com](https://www.legacy.com/us/obituaries/baytobaynews-md/name/joseph-era-obituary?id=20351615#:~:text=his%20devoted%20dog%2C%20Pancho%3B%20son,nieces%2C%20Leslie%20Fetzer%20of%20Pa)). She has not made any public statements on development, and her name did not appear in recent county meeting discussions on local solar projects ([www.wboc.com](https://www.wboc.com/archive/east-new-market-citizens-concerned-about-solar-farm-project/article_23b7861f-6bd3-5c6f-8422-e5a52ced3933.html#:~:text=WBOC%20spoke%20with%20neighbors%20at,are%20concerned%20about%20this%20project)).

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage her through a community connection (such as a church or veterans’ group peer) who can emphasize plans for preserving agricultural heritage and safeguarding home values during the project’s development.

neighbors.name: Harpers Legacy LLC
neighbors.claims: Harpers Legacy LLC is a Maryland limited liability company that owns multiple parcels of land in Dorchester County (approximately 145.8 acres near Linkwood) ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=Councilman%20Satterfield%20made%20a%20motion,Mr)). County records indicate this LLC’s property (on Harper Road near Hurlock) was selected as the site of a 20 MW solar farm (Todd Solar), with a 35-year lease agreement approved in 2018 ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=Councilman%20Satterfield%20made%20a%20motion,Mr)). The County’s tax agreement for that project applied only to the solar equipment, confirming Harpers Legacy LLC retained land ownership during the solar development ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=business%20personal%20property%2C%20not%20the,land)) ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=Councilman%20Satterfield%20made%20a%20motion,Mr)). No other business operations are noted for Harpers Legacy LLC; its activities appear limited to holding and leasing land for investment purposes ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=Councilman%20Satterfield%20made%20a%20motion,Mr)).
neighbors.influence_justification: Owns ~145 acres used in a major solar project; local landowner but no known broader civic role

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage principal owners quietly with win-win proposals (e.g., revenue sharing); emphasize respect for land legacy; anticipate openness to development that offers financial upside

neighbors.name: Edmondson Agriculture LLC
neighbors.claims: Edmondson Agriculture LLC is a family-run farming entity based in Cambridge, Maryland ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=24019&page=19&progcode=total#:~:text=,%2441%2C988)). The LLC has received approximately $42,096 in federal farm program payments from 1995–2024, reflecting active agricultural operations on its Dorchester County land ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/top_recips.php?fips=24019&page=19&progcode=total#:~:text=,%2441%2C988)). The Edmondson family (e.g., Cornelia J. Edmondson of Cambridge) has separately received substantial farm subsidies, suggesting this LLC is part of a longstanding local farm enterprise ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/addrsearch.php?page=2&z=1&zip=21613#:~:text=,%24%20129%2C893.73)) ([farm.ewg.org](https://farm.ewg.org/addrsearch.php?page=2&z=1&zip=21613#:~:text=67%20%20,%24%20127%2C517.35)). No records indicate involvement in commercial development beyond farming; the company’s interests seem focused on crop production and land stewardship.
neighbors.influence_justification: Moderate-size family farm; known in farming community but limited political or economic clout

approach_recommendations.engage: Approach via personal outreach emphasizing respect for farming needs; highlight how the project can coexist with agriculture (buffer zones, etc.); address any concerns about soil, water, or long-term land use

neighbors.name: Dorchester County, Maryland
neighbors.claims: Dorchester County (local government) owns land adjoining Linkwood WMA, reflecting the county’s role in managing public assets ([dnr.maryland.gov](https://dnr.maryland.gov/wildlife/Pages/publiclands/eastern/linkwood.aspx#:~:text=forest%20ecosystem%2C%20Linkwood%20WMA%20is,wide%20range%20of%20forest%20animals)) ([dnr.maryland.gov](https://dnr.maryland.gov/wildlife/Pages/publiclands/eastern/linkwood.aspx#:~:text=Image%3A%20Linkwood%20WMA%20is%20located,Directions)). The County Council has shown a generally pro-development stance when it benefits the public; in 2018, the Council approved a 35-year Payment in Lieu of Taxes (PILOT) agreement for a 20 MW solar facility, citing significant long-term revenue for schools and services ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=Councilman%20Satterfield%20made%20a%20motion,Mr)) ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=Councilman%20Satterfield%20stated%20that%20the,He%20advised%20that%20the%20Planning)). County officials have balanced economic development with resident concerns – for example, requiring landscape buffers around energy projects to address community feedback ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=Shiloh%20Camp%20Road%20and%20perhaps,Todd%20said%20during%20a%20State)) ([mdstatewire.com](https://mdstatewire.com/dorchester-county-council-met-october-2/#:~:text=Councilman%20Satterfield%20made%20a%20motion,Mr)). As the governing authority, Dorchester County influences zoning, permits, and tax policy for any new development in the area.
neighbors.influence_justification: Local governing body with regulatory power and control over land use and tax incentives

approach_recommendations.engage: Engage county officials openly through formal channels; emphasize tax benefits and compliance with county plans; build community support to align with county’s public interest mandate

overview_summary: None of the five adjacent landowners have a documented stance for or against the development – all are currently categorized as unknown in terms of support or opposition. Two come from longstanding local farm families that carry significant social capital in Dorchester County, whereas the others appear to have relatively lower public profiles or community influence. All profiled neighbors have no documented public stance regarding the development, with 0 openly supporting or opposing it. One neighbor holds a high-impact position (the long-serving county sheriff), while the others appear to have low community influence due to limited public roles. All five neighboring landowners have no documented public stance on development or clean energy, so their positions remain unknown. None holds any official local government role or overt community leadership; overall their influence in the community appears to be low. None of the four profiled neighbors has made a public statement supporting or opposing the Linkwood area development, so all are currently classified with unknown stances. Their community influence appears limited, as none hold public office or prominent leadership roles locally. Most are private landowners with minimal public profiles, indicating that any concerns or opposition they might have would likely remain low-profile and individual. None of the five adjacent landowners has a publicly documented stance either supporting or opposing the project. Most maintain a low profile in the community, with one notable exception: a long-established farming family patriarch who carries moderate influence due to his family’s generations of local farming. Two local individual landowners were identified, neither of whom has a publicly documented stance on development. Both appear to have limited public profiles, and no direct evidence of support or opposition was found. Community influence among these neighbors is generally low, with one having some familial ties to local civic circles. Concerns common in the area include preserving farmland and home values, reflecting issues raised by other nearby residents. The adjacent landowners around Linkwood WMA include private LLCs tied to local farming interests and the county government. Two family-linked LLCs (Harpers Legacy LLC and Edmondson Agriculture LLC) own nearby farmlands, while Dorchester County owns a parcel as public land. These entities likely prioritize land value, agricultural use, and community considerations in evaluating new development. None appear to be large corporations; their influence stems more from land ownership and local ties than organized development activity, though the county government wields regulatory power.
